Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of woman(?) playing tambourine, wearing helmet and necklace, but otherwise naked. Handmade in primitive style with traces of painted red decoration on helmet. Broken at waist, missing body and legs. Pale buff fabric with fine white and black inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ16 or 17
Curator's comments: Karageorghis argues that a strong Phoenician influence during the 8th to 7th centuries BC on coroplastics resulted in this type of terracotta figure. Similar examples have been found in Cyprus that persist until the early 5th century BC (Karageorghis 1995, pls 19.12-15, 20.1-9, Types 1(vii)7-16 and pl. 21.1, type I(viii)2 for helmet), though this cannot be given a more refined date. This 'helmet' is unusual for a female figure. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.028) (Phase 1)
